sen.j: 国立銀行紙幣（こくりつぎんこうしへい）とは明治の初期に国立銀行 (明治)が発行した紙幣である。
sen.e: Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was paper currency issued by the National Bank in the early Meiji Period.
Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was paper currency issued by the National Bank in the early Meiji Period.
Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was paper currency issued by the National Bank in the early Meiji Period.

sen.j: 明治維新以降に発行されていた明治通宝などは不換紙幣（主に金や銀の本位貨幣と交換が保証されていない紙幣）であり、当時は金本位制が国際的な流れで日本でも兌換紙幣（本位貨幣と交換が保障されている紙幣）を発行する必要性があった。
sen.e: Currencies such as Meiji Tsuho (government note in Meiji Period) which was issued after the Meiji Restoration were inconvertible paper currency (paper currency which was not assured an exchange with standard money, such as gold and silver), and at that time, gold standard system was an international trend, so Japan also needed to issue convertible currency (paper currency which was assured an exchange with standard money).

Currencies such as Meiji Tsuho (government note in Meiji Period) which was issued after the Meiji Restoration were inconvertible paper currency (paper currency which was not assured an exchange with standard money, such as gold and silver), and at that time, gold standard system was an international trend, so Japan also needed to issue convertible currency (paper currency which was assured an exchange with standard money).

Currencies such as Meiji Tsuho (government note in Meiji Period) which was issued after the Meiji Restoration were inconvertible paper currency (paper currency which was not assured an exchange with standard money, such as gold and silver), and at that time, gold standard system was an international trend, so Japan also needed to issue convertible currency (paper currency which was assured an exchange with standard money).

sen.j: 明治政府は金本位制度の確立を民間に任せることとし、1872年に国立銀行条例（民間資本で発券銀行を設立し兌換紙幣の発行を義務付けるというもの。）を制定した。
sen.e: The Meiji Government left an establishment of the gold standard system to the private sector, and in 1872, and enacted a regulation of national bank (to establish issue banks with private capital, and oblige issuance of convertible currency).
sen.cmt: 「）を制定した。」の部分が次のセルに分かれていたので、ひとつにしました。
sen.e: The Meiji Government left an establishment of the gold standard system to the private sector, and enacted a regulation of national bank in 1872, (to establish issue banks with private capital, and oblige them to issue convertible currency).
sen.cmt: and in 1872: and を削除し、in 1872 の場所を変更しました。oblige issuance of oblige ⇒ them to issue に訂正しました。
sen.e: The Meiji Government left an establishment of the gold standard system to the private sector, and enacted a regulation of national bank in 1872, (to establish issue banks with private capital, and oblige them to issue convertible currency).

sen.j: これにより4行の国立銀行 (明治)が設立され、1873年から兌換紙幣の国立銀行紙幣が発行された。
sen.e: Four national banks (in Meiji Period) were built and convertible Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was issued since 1873.
Four national banks (in Meiji Period) were built and convertible Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was issued since 1873.
Four national banks (in Meiji Period) were built and convertible Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was issued since 1873.

sen.j: しかし金貨の不足から経営不振に陥り、やむなく国立銀行条例を改正し不換紙幣の発行が認められるようになってからは銀行の数が急増し、新たな国立銀行紙幣（不換紙幣）が発行された。
sen.e: But they ran into financial difficulty due to the lack of gold coins, and since the regulation of national bank was forced to be amended to permit issuance of inconvertible currency, number of banks increased abruptly and new Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei (inconvertible currency) was issued.

But they ran into financial difficulty due to the lack of gold coins, and since the regulation of national bank was forced to be amended to permit issuance of inconvertible currency, the number of banks increased abruptly and new Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei (inconvertible currency) was issued.
sen.cmt: the number of banks に訂正しました。
sen.e: But they ran into financial difficulty due to the lack of gold coins, and since the regulation of national bank was forced to be amended to permit issuance of inconvertible currency, the number of banks increased abruptly and new Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei (inconvertible currency) was issued.

sen.j: 各銀行が発行したため発行者名は銀行ごとに異なるが額面や形式は統一されている。
sen.e: Being issued by each banks, names of issuance varied by banks, but the face value and the forms were unified.
Being issued by each bank, names of issuers varied by banks, but the face value and the forms were unified.
sen.cmt: each bank に訂正しました。names of issuers に訂正しました。
sen.e: Being issued by each bank, names of issuers varied by banks, but the face value and the forms were unified.

sen.j: また印刷は兌換紙幣に関してはアメリカ合衆国で行われた。
sen.e: And convertible currency was printed in the United States.
In addition, convertible currency was printed in the United States.
sen.cmt: And ⇒ In addition, に訂正しました。
sen.e: In addition, convertible currency was printed in the United States.

sen.j: いずれの紙幣もアメリカ合衆国に製造を外注した。
sen.e: Production of each currency was outsourced to the United States.
Production of each currency was outsourced to the United States.
Production of each currency was outsourced to the United States.

sen.j: 表面 タヂマモリと兵船
sen.e: Face Tajimamori (ancient Japanese figure and also worshiped as a god of sweets) and a ship for wars
Face Tajimamori (ancient Japanese figure and also worshiped as a god of sweets) and a ship for wars

sen.j: 紙幣寮を国立印刷局と改め、洋式印刷で国内製造を始めた。
sen.e: Shiheiryo (paper money office) was renamed to National Printing Bureau which started to produce domestically by western printing.
Shiheiryo (paper money office) was renamed to National Printing Bureau which started to produce domestically by western printing.
Shiheiryo (paper money office) was renamed to National Printing Bureau which started to produce domestically by western printing.
Back Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce)
Back Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce)
Back Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce)

sen.j: 日本銀行の設立により改造紙幣とともに、1899年12月に通用停止となった。
sen.e: Due to the establishment of the Bank of Japan, they became uncurrent as well as Kaizo Shihei (convertible currency issed by the Meiji government), in December, 1899.
Due to the establishment of the Bank of Japan, they became uncurrent as well as Kaizo Shihei (convertible currency issed by the Meiji government), in December, 1899.
Due to the establishment of the Bank of Japan, they became uncurrent as well as Kaizo Shihei (convertible currency issed by the Meiji government), in December, 1899.
